The discovery of lithium as a treatment is actually more interesting than just John Cade. It was first used in the 19th century when uric acid was discovered as the causative agent in gout. People jumped on the uric acid bandwagon and started thinking it was the cause of many other disorders, including bipolar disorder. They knew back then lithium dissolved uric acid, so they used it to treat bipolar disorder. They stopped when the gout fad faded, and because of toxicity. Lithium chloride was then used as a salt replacement in the 1920s when scientists discovered the role of sodium in causing hypertension. People realized the calming effects then, too, and it got to the point it was included in the original 7-Up recipe. This caused a lot of overdoses, which is what lead to it being banned. It was used as a treatment for bipolar disorder following Cade's experiments in the 1950s onwards but didn't become commonplace until the 1970s when adequate blood testing became available. Lithium is unique among the medications for mental illness in that it is not only the first true effective psychiatric medication, it was actually discovered three times.

Method & Apparatus for Translating the EEG into Music...

Abstract: A method and apparatus for applying a musical feedback signal to the human brain, or any other brain, to induce controllable psychological and physiological responses. A signal representing the ongoing electroencephalographic (EEG) signal of a brain preferably is obtained from the electrode location on the scalp known as CZ or P3 in clinical notation. A signal processor converts the ongoing EEG into electrical signals which are converted into music by synthesizers. The music is acoustically fed back to the brain after a time delay calculated to shift the phase of the feedback in order to reinforce specific or desired ongoing EEG activity from the scalp position of interest. The music is comprised of at least one voice that follows the moment-by-moment contour of the EEG in real time to reinforce the desired EEG activity. The music drives the brain into resonance with the music to provide a closed loop or physiological feedback effect. Preferably, the musical feedback comprises additional voices that embody psychoacoustic principles as well as provide the content and direction normally supplied by the therapist in conventional biofeedback. The invention contemplates numerous applications for the results obtained. USP # 4,877,027 (October 31, 1989)

Method & Apparatus for Remotely Determining Information as to Person's Emotional State ~

Abstract: In a method for remotely determining information relating to a person's emotional state, an waveform energy having a predetermined frequency and a predetermined intensity is generated and wirelessly transmitted towards a remotely located subject. Waveform energy emitted from the subject is detected and automatically analyzed to derive information relating to the individual's emotional state. Physiological or physical parameters of blood pressure, pulse rate, pupil size, respiration rate and perspiration level are measured and compared with reference values to provide information utilizable in evaluating interviewee's responses or possibly criminal intent in security sensitive areas. USP # 5,522,386 (June 4, 1996)

Hearing System

Abstract: Sound is induced in the head of a person by radiating the head with microwaves in the range of 100 megahertz to 10,000 megahertz that are modulated with a particular waveform. The waveform consists of frewuency modulated bursts. each burst is made up of 10 to 20 uniformly spaced pulses grouped tightly together. the burst width is between 500 nanoseconds and 100 microseconds. The pulse width is in the range of 10 nanoseconds to 1 microsecond. The bursts are frequency modulated by the audio input to create the sensation of hearing in the person whose head is irradiated. USP # 4,858,612 (August 22, 1989)

I'm not sure I agree that the solubility of CO2 decreases with increasing temperatures. Increasing the temperature of liquids in general hastens gas exchange rates, but that goes both ways. If you actively try to pump CO2 in a liquid which due to temperature has an increased gas exchange rate, it will dissolve easier. Maybe I'm dead wrong when it comes to Lithium Hydroxide, but I have a fair bit of experience with CO2 dissolution in agitated water at different temperatures. Hell, I've been specifically making CO2 for years for use in my fish tanks by adding sodium bicarbonate to citric acid dissolved in distilled water.

I have Bipolar Disorder. Types 1 and 2 are of equal severity, but in different ways. Type 1 - what I have- is where a person experiences extended periods of mania and depression. Type 2, however, is where a person experiences even longer periods of depression with periods of brief relief with hypomania. Cyclothymia, however, is much less severe, as the cycles don't go all the way down into depression, and the hypomania doesn't last for more than a day or two, and it is usually treated with anti-convulsants instead of lithium salts. Also, the dose and frequency of lithium salts depends on which one you take, and also how well your body metabolizes it. I metabolize lithium carbonate quite fast, so, I have to take quite a bit to maintain a blood level that is effective for me.

2:40 No, no, no! Absolutely not true! When it comes to bipolar disorder, lithium is gold. It can treat all phases of bipolar disorder, and prevent or slow down the cycling between phases; no other medication can do that, or is nearly as effective. As well, lithium is one of the few medications in modern psychopharmacology that can reduce obsessive thoughts about suicides, as well as reduce deaths from suicide.

The downside is that it requires close monitoring, both in terms of watching for symptomatic side-effects, as well as watching for blood levels, white blood cell counts, and kidney function tests. However, I humbly submit that any competent psychiatrist should be able to use this drug safely, and with confidence. It's almost as old as dirt, so there won't be many surprises. We're very familiar with its side-effects, and know very well how to prevent or manage them.

The only advantage of the newer drugs is that they're more "user friendly." The blood levels don't fluctuate as much, and in many cases, they don't require monitoring of blood levels at all. There's room for debate whether they have fewer or less severe side-effects. I believe it's a toss-up there. However, no medication matches the dependable, sheer brute efficacy of lithium.

Dear fellow bipolar people:

Though this video is interesting and medicinal Lithium Carbonate can be expensive to buy (as I know from experience), for fuck's sake, don't be tempted to make and ingest your own Lithium Carbonate as you could very easily overdose. Lithium is highly toxic and overdosing, or just taking your regular dose and forgetting to hydrate, causes lithium toxicity, which among other things, is a slow and painful death. It's very hard to tell that it's happening and it is subtle and progressive, its effects comparable with getting drunk.

TL;DR: interesting experiment but do not try this at home, kids.

The manic episodes in bipolar type 1 are not always 7 days or longer, when it comes to rapid cycling they may be as short as a few days, hours or even minutes. However in order to be diagnosed with bipolar type 1 disorder you must experience at least one manic episode in your life lasting 7 days or longer. Also, bipolar type 2 is not necessarily less severe than type 1, while they typically experience less severe forms of mania known as hypomania, they are more prone to experiencing longer and more severe episodes of major depression.

I am going to have to argue against the claim that Lithium is the most used drug for treating bipolar disorder (and also that more useful drugs have been developed.) As person who suffers from bipolar 1 disorder, I was at my wits end, having gone through so many different types of medications to help with it. It wasn't until I realized that SSRI's actually made things either worse or unbearable, that I stuck with an atypical antidepressant which barely scratched the surface. At one point, I had a doctor that ordered an anticonvulsant, carbamazapine for me; being that I had briefly taken it before and it significantly helped with the mood changes; only to have him call me before I got home from that appointment telling me that it was contraindicated with my heart condition. He tried me on a drug that was new and I couldn't afford and really didn't help much. I finally ended up having such a bad manic episode that I came home from work and literally crept to the window with every sound, convinced that my coworkers had sent men in white coats to come and take me away. (This is particularly unusual as I am a nurse and know very well that the system does not work that way.) I went to my doctor in desperation and begged him to try me on one of the only two other meds I had not tried before. I chose Lithium and he said the only way he could do it responsibly, given my agitated state, was to have me placed for observation in a psych ward while I was started on it. Again, out of desperation, I agreed. I have never been better since. Lithium really is a miracle treatment for bipolar disorder and even my doctor said that the reason it is so rarely prescribed is due to the its unpatentablity that doctors don't get kick backs from the drug companies for prescribing it. I have also seen in my career many people who do very well without it but on newer meds and with some investigation, it turns out that they perhaps only have a mild form of bipolar disorder, if at all. While many who really do have the tried and true symptoms, still struggle very much without Lithium while those who do take it do very well. In my experience, only about 5-10% of those with true bipolar disorder are on this medication. There has also been research done on people in towns whose water supply comes from aquifers that have higher than normal trace amounts of Lithium and they are among the most peaceful and happy folks around.

The major two dangers of consuming Lithium is toxicity if regular blood levels are not being checked, and the fact that if you do not keep hydrated enough (it has a tendency to make you more prone to dehydration) then the levels in your blood can rise, causing toxicity. This is why it is dangerous to consume alcohol regularly while taking it and why people who work in extremely hot conditions where it is difficult to stay hydrated (like my mom who used to work out in the fields) should avoid it. Among the first side effects of toxicity is tremors. I found that the co-prescribed medication to help the tremors was worse than the tremors themselves, and if I get them, I just hydrate myself better and they go away.

Oddly enough, "Lithium water" is a real thing you can buy at health food stores without a prescription. I know one lady who completely controls her bipolar disorder with it alone. But again, not being under the supervision of a doctor who can regularly test blood levels, this is potentially dangerous as well.

BUT... A big thanks for this educational intro!!! <3

The SSRIs are not known if they help by increasing serotonin and the serotonin itself resolves depression, or if the serotonin is what's causing depression and the increase in ambient serotonin causes downregulation which yields antidepressive effect. As someone who ran the whole gamut of psych meds a decade ago, I can say that the only way they 'worked' was when I was zombified and couldn't feel one way or the other anymore. I had to learn how to just be comfortable with myself and be motivated to take better care of myself in more ways than one. If any of the meds did help, I'd say lithium helped the most, the rest of them caused more problems than they solved, especially if I found myself in a situation where I had no access to them and had to go 'cold turkey' - that was a literal waking nightmare.
